page.title: 01Ingalee Skerry Strongay
page.content: Ingale Skerry is a small outcrop of rock 1 Kilometre south of Stronsay, between Stronsay and Auskerry. It is about 200 mtrs in length and 50 mtrs wide lying in a north-west-southeast direction. There is no vegetation on ingale skerry apart from seaweed, as it is completely covered by water during high tide. The skerry is a frequent resting place for the seals, which live around Orkney, during low tide. Other visitors include oystercatchers and morants. The tides around Ingale Skerry are strong, consequently it is difficult and dangerous to attempt a landing by Boat.
